Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/pfsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? >What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

Learn something new. De-botnet your life. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. What is the term for how fast a microcontroller can change the current it's outputting? I want to find one that can swap the direction of current really fast, and don't know what to look up.
Thank you

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89964529
Thank you; this is my first time using microcontrollers and I have no idea wtf I'm doing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89964565
Next tip: Output pins are typically 3.3 volts and really low current. If you're trying to control anything more power hungry than a small LED, you'll want to connect that output pin to a mosfet to switch a power source with more current. If you're trying to switch polarity rather than on/off, you can use a single pin connected to a mosfet switching current going one way, and also a not gate going to another mosfet switching current going the other way. Or you can use 2 pins, each going to a mosfet switching current a different way - this adds a 3rd state you can select: off. Technically there's also a 4th state: turn both on to create a short and make smoke.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89964476

Furthermore, its clients will be able to upgrade their machines without replacing actual hardware or offering additional services to their clients. Intel's upcoming Intel's 4th Generation Xeon processors are equipped with various special-purpose accelerators and security technologies that all customers do not need at all times.

To offer such end-users additional flexibility regarding investments,

>Intel will deliver them to buy its CPUs with those capabilities disabled but turn them on if they are needed at some point.

<You will pay Intel and they send you a code to unlock your CPUs full power.

<Once unlocked the CPU will not accidentally revert back to limited state of operability.

The Software Defined Silicon (SDSi) technology will also allow Intel to sell fewer CPU models and then enable its clients or partners to activate certain features if needed. The list of technologies that Intel wants to make available on demand includes Software Guard Extensions, Dynamic Load Balancer (DLB), Intel Data Streaming Accelerator (DSA), Intel In-Memory Analytics Accelerator (IAA), Intel In-Memory Analytics Accelerator, and Intel QuickAssist Technology (QAT) to accelerate specific workloads.

But with the Amiga, I actually started buying games, at least the ones I liked and could still find easily in the local shops. I also got copies of some games from friends, never refused those because it wasn't always easy to find stuff, especially older titles. But I did buy a lot of stuff too. >>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases

>>89962841
in the unlikely singularity event, "just turning it off" amounts to turning off most technological devices on earth, forever. if you succeed, then humanity is back where it was in the 1940s, except the resulting negative growth will blow up the financial system and just about everything else, too, and you'll have far fewer resources available this time around. lots of struggle, many people die, etc.

>The only plausible way would be for AI to manipulate govenment officials en masse in a huge psy-op and even then there’s no saying that they’d perfectly predict the right play.
singularity tier AI would be massively useful, so it's unlikely that you could get everyone to agree to discard it. e.g. nuclear weapons are also massively useful but very dangerous, and yet every major power keeps them around just in case. always remember: human competition trumps all else; all other fears. it's the one rule that's been constant through all of civilization.

personally, while i don't see the singularity happening, i already find the prospect of people talking to bots and not knowing about it very worrying. i certainly don't want to partake in such an internet myself. same goes for engagement optimization AI.

>>89963076
I'll try an make it simple to understand since you're appear to be extremely new to the topic: all watches that take batteries are quartz watches (no matter if they've got a digital display or analog spinning hands) . Because the way they keep time is that there's a component inside that contains a miniscule quartz crystal. when one puts electricity through it, it vibrates at a high but very constant frequency, about 32000 tines a second. Since this frequency us so constant, we know how often it vibrates in one second and can thus use it to measure time: every 32000 vibrations a second goes by. This is used in all electrical devices that keep time in any way, including computers and phones.
The much older, non-electric alternative are mechanical watches. they use a series of spinning gears and springs to keep time. this happens without any electricity, the springs just need to be wound up. if there's a ritating mechanism inside that winds the spring a bit whenever the watch is moved, a mechanical watch is called Automatic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89963891
every package in arch linux is defined in a pkgbuild
a pkgbuild is just a bash script in a specific format
it's very easy to read and the manpage is excellent at explaining every detail if you need it

the aur is just a collection of pkgbuilds
the default repos are basically the same thing but only public maintainers can upload to them

reading a pkgbuild is a lot easier than unpacking a rpm/deb tarball every time you want to update with confidence
it also helps that arch packages generally try to stay close to upstream, so you don't have to factor in distro-specific patches most of the time

The only worthwhile game I found is Beat Saber, and it's the best rhythm game I've played since SDVX. Community maps have gotten good, there's basically never ending source of content. This game alone makes VR worth it.

- Boneworks: Portal vibes "you shouldn't be here", object physics and creepy enemies, visceral janky combat, extremely immersive. Got bored later though.
- Jet Island feels like theme park ride with the heavy movement and high speed, very surreal experience
- Dreadhalls is a procedurally generated labyrinth escape horror game, no cheap jump scares, still very scary. The real scale in VR makes enemies feel threatening.
- Half Life Alyx has great graphics and nice post-apocalyptic city environments but was so boring I dropped it

The problem with VR is the barrier of entry, which makes most games just not worth the physical effort. Also the jank of different VR hardware takes away from the intended experience, it never feels quite right. Fully integrated systems like PSVR2 will provide better experience.
